explanation: The report is correct. The statement uri[uri_len] = 0 unconditionally writes a NUL one past the last byte when the caller supplies a buffer whose allocated size is exactly uri_len. That is an out‑of‑bounds write (undefined behavior). Although the direct memchr/memcmp calls in this function are invoked with explicit lengths (so those calls alone would not necessarily read past uri_len), the code then calls daemon->unescape_callback (and other string processing functions in callbacks) which typically expect NUL-terminated strings and may call functions from <string.h> (strlen, strchr, etc.). If the NUL was written out of bounds, those string.h calls can therefore access beyond the object bounds, violating MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. The root cause is the unguarded write at uri[uri_len]; the safe fix is to ensure the buffer has space for the NUL (or avoid writing it and pass explicit lengths to functions that accept them).
